projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head:
An Almanacke for the yeare of our Lord God 1609.
〈◊〉 and 〈◊〉 by 〈◊〉 Neue

table.head: Sun riſeth at viii. of the clock, and iiii. minutes. And ſetteth at iii. and 56. minutes.

row.cell: ☽ Firſt quarter the 2. day, at 11 of the the clocke and. 56. minutes at night.
● The ful moon the 10 day, 55 minutes after one of the clocke in the morning.
☾ Laſt quarter the 18. day, 8. minutes after ii of the clock, in the morning.
● New moone, the 25. day, 8. minutes after three of the clock, in the afternoon

table.head: Sun riſeth at vii. of the clock, and xiiii. minutes. Setteth at 4 and 46 minutes.

row.cell: ☽ Firſt quarter the 1. day 39 minutes after 7 of the clocke in the morning.
● Full Moone the 8. day, 16. minutes after 6. of the clocke at night
☾ Laſt quarter the 16. day, 55. minutes after 9. of the clocke at night.
● New moone the 24 day, 37. minutes after one of the clock in the morning.

table.head: Sun riſeth at vi. of the clock, and xviii. minutes. Setteth at v. and xiii. minutes.

row.cell: ☽ Firſt quarter the 2. day 45. minutes after 4 of the clocke at night.
● Full Moon the 10. day, 35. minutes before high noone.
☾ Laſt quarter the 18. day, 37. minutes after 2. of the clocke in the afternoone.
● New moone the 25. day, 9. minutes after a 11. of the clock, in the forenoon.

table.head: Sun riſeth at v. of the clocke, and xx. minutes. Setteth at vi. and xi. minutes.

row.cell: ¶ Firſt quarter, the firſt day, 30. minutes after three of the clocke in the morning.
¶ Full moon the 9. day, halfe an houre after 4. of the clock, in the morning.
☾ Laſt quarter, the 17. day 36. minutes, after three of the clocke in the morning.
● New Moon the 23 day, 17 minutes after vii. of the clock at night.
☽ Firſt quarter the 30. day, at fiue of the clocke at night.

table.head: Sun riſeth at iiii. of the clock, and xxxvi. minutes. Setteth at vii. and xxiiii. minutes.

row.cell: ● Full Moone the 8. day, 30 minutes after 8. of the clocke at night.

☾ Laſt quarter the
• 6. day, at one of the clock in the afternoone.
● New Moon the 23. day, 14 minutes after 3. of the clock, in the morning.
☽ Firſt quarter the 30. day about 8. of the clock in the morning.

table.head: Sun riſeth at iii. of the clocke, and xlvii. minutes. Setteth at viii. and xiii. minutes.

row.cell: ● Full moone the 7. day, 47. minutes after 10. of the clock in the forenoone.
☾ Laſt quarter the 14. day, 25. minutes after 7. of the clock at night.
● New moone the 21. day, 20 minutes before high noone.
¶ Firſt quarter 29 day, halfe an houre before one of the clocke in the morning.

table.head: Sun riſeth after 4. of the clock 12. minutes. Setteth after 7. 48. minutes.

row.cell: ● Full Moone the 6 day, 18. minutes after 11 of the clocke at night.
¶ Laſt quarter the 13, day about midnight.
● New moon the 20 day, 38. minutes after 9 of the clocke at night.
☽ Firſt quarter the 28. day, 50. minutes after 5. of the clocke at night.

table.head: Sun riſeth after 4. of the clock xxxvii. minutes. Setteth after 7. 23. minutes.

row.cell: ● Full moone the 5. day, 23. minutes after 10. of the clock. 〈◊〉 the forenoone.
☾ Laſt quarter the 12. day, 40. minutes after 4. of the clocke, in the morning.
● New Moon the 19. day, 40. minutes after ix. of the clocke, in the forenoone.
☽ Firſt quarter, the 27. day 26. minutes after 11 of the clock in the forenoone.

table.head: Sun riſeth after 5. of the clock 36. minutes. Setteth after 6. • 4. minutes.

row.cell: ● Full Moone the 3. Day, about 8. of the clocke at night.
☾ Laſt quarter the: 0. day, 50. minutes after 10. of clocke in the forenoone.
● New Moon the 18. day▪ 40. minutes before one of the clock in the morning.
☽ Firſt quarter, the 26. day, 2 • . minutes after iiii. of the clock in the morning.

table.head: Sun riſeth after 6. of the clock 36. minutes, Setteth after v. xxiiii. minutes.

row.cell: ● Ful Moone the 3. day, 55. minutes after 6. of the clock in the morning.
☾ Laſt quarter the 9. day, 18 minutes after 8. of the clocke at night.
● New Moon the 1 • . day, 24. minutes after 5. of the clock at night.
☽ Firſt quarter, the 25. day, 8. minutes after 8. of the clocke at night.

table.head: Sun riſeth after 7. of the clock xxiii. minutes. Setteth after iiii. xxxvii. minutes.

row.cell: ● Full Moone, the firſt day, a little before 3. of the clocke in the after noone.
☾ Laſt quarter the 8 day, 27. minutes after ix. of the clocke, in the morning.
● New Moone the 16 day, about high noone.
☾ Firſt quarter, the 24. day, 40. minutes after 9. of the clocke. in the morning.

table.head: Sun riſeth after 8. of the clock 12. minutes. Setteth after 3. 48. minutes.

row.cell: ● Full Moone, the 1. day, a little before one of the clock in the morning.
☾ Laſt quarter the 8. day, 24, minutes, after 2 of the clocke in the morning.
● New Moon the 16. day, 50. minutes after 6. of the clock in the morning.
☾ Firſt quarter the 23. day, 14, minutes after 8. of the clocke at night.
● Full moone the 30. day, about high noone.

p.hi: • Thirtie dayes hath September, Aprill, Iune, and Nouember. February hath xxviii. alone: And all the reſt thirtie and one.

div.head: ¶ For this 〈…〉 our Lord 〈◊〉 according to the accompt and computation of the 〈…〉 of England.
div.p: Betweene Chriſtmas and Shroue-Sunday, is euen ix. weekes. Sundayes after Trinitie.

list.head:
¶ 〈…〉
••
yond Sea account, note that their
list.item: The Circle of the Sunn • xxii

div.p: Betweene Chriſtmas and Shroue ſunday, are ix. weeks, and three dayes.
NOte, that it is not conuenient to let bloud, whilſt the Moone paſſe by Tau. Capr. Gem. Leo. and Scorp. or the Moone neere the change, full, or quarters: or being afflicted by Satur. or Mars.
The Moone in Aries well affected, is a fit time to let bloud ſuch as bee of a Sanguine or Flegmatick complexion.
The Moone in Canc. let bloude the cholericke complexion.
The Moone in Aqua. or Libra. fitteth the Melancholicke.
Sheare your sheepe, to haue them deepe fleeced: pole or cut your hayre to auoyd baldneſſe: ſet and remooue young trees to haue them growe the better and fayter, in the increaſe of the Moone.
The wane of the Moone, ſhee being in Aries. Sagit. or Capr. maketh an approued time to lib or geld cattell.

figure.figDesc: diagram of human body as microcosm (with members corresponding to zodiacal signs)

lg.l: In heade and face is Aries place,
But armes & hands in Geminies bands,
And Leo backe and heart he hath,
take thou with all their paines,
For Libra loe the buttockes hath,
to haue loe ſtill ſhe cries:
For ſure ſhe is that Sagittarie,
Then Capricorne muſt rule the knees,
And Piſces purchaſt hath the feete:

div.p: Imprinted at London for the Company of the 〈…〉 .
